Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_2.name: 7d4b
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_2.text: In the heart of an Android app there are a multitude of async tasks like handling user inputs, network calls and accessing the persistence layer. The problem is that asynchronous tasks increase the complexity of state management by a considerable amount.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_3.name: 131c
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_3.text: Jake Wharton showed one way to solve the state management problem with RxJava in his talk titled Managing State with RxJava. But there is one issue with this approach: in order to keep the state of the app correct all async tasks must be part of the same RxJava’s stream so that it can all be coordinated properly. This results in an incredible entanglement of complex and composed RxJava’s operators. Some of those operators are hard to master, thus making the code hard to read for devs that haven’t mastered RxJava yet.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_4.name: 4c49
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_4.text: “So, RxJava is bad, now what!?”. No no no no, RxJava is pretty awesome. The problem here is that managing the state of the app, or the UI, using RxJava’s alone can be a daunting task. Wouldn’t it be much better if we could write most of our UI logic in old, synchronous code? Well, that’s what Kelm tries to do!

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_5.name: cf0e
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_5.text:
AllanHasegawa/kelm
Kelm simplifies management of complex app states and asynchronous tasks. Kelm is a Kotlin library based on the Elm…github.com

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_7.text: Kelm is an open source Kotlin-only library powered by RxJava that aims to ease the state management of modern Android apps.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_8.name: c278
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_8.text: Kelm forces a clean separation between executing async tasks from handling their events. Async tasks are handled by RxJava streams, while handling their events is done by a pure synchronous function. This allows you to still use the power of RxJava, but code most of the UI logic in simple synchronous code.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_9.name: b5d4
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_9.text: Kelm? Haven’t I heard about it?

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_10.text: Probably. Kelm was heavily inspired by the Elm Architecture. Kelm also follows the Unidirectional Data Flow pattern.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_12.name: e43d
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_12.text: The Model in the diagram is the state of the app. The Update is where most of an app’s logic is. It’s a pure function that takes the previous Model and a Message as input and returns a new Model.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_13.name: 93ed
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_13.text: The red part represents the pure part of the system. It has no side-effects and is completely synchronous, so it’s pretty awesome that this is where most of our code is.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_14.name: 31a2
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_14.text: The green part is where the side-effects and async tasks are. The Update can return Commands, that in turn are mapped to RxJava’s Maybe. These Maybe then return Messages that will then be passed to the Update. And the cycle is complete.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_16.name: 5d00
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_16.text: The following is a simple Kelm program that have three buttons on screen: a plus, a minus and a reset. Can you read this code and understand what it does?

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_18.name: 6d19
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_18.text: In this sample we have the Model being a simple counter with derivative properties that control the enabled state for the reset and minus buttons. The messages are the user actions.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_19.name: 7ea0
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_19.text: Where’s the async stuff? What about side-effects?

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_20.name: 151f
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_20.text: Kelm doesn’t allow any async calls nor side effects in its Update function. For that Kelm uses the concept of Commands. Commands are simple tasks that run and return a Message in the future. To use Commands you implement a Kelm Element.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_21.name: 727f
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_21.text: This next sample showcases a full implementation of an app that requests random pictures of foxes from a REST API. When the request fails the user is prompted to retry.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_23.name: 24c6
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_23.text: Note how Messages are used for both user inputs and responses from the service.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_24.name: 41a2
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_24.text: A Command is then mapped to an RxJava’s Maybe:

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_26.name: cd03
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_26.text: That’s cute, but can it handle the real world?

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_27.name: a8f2
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_27.text: You can check the more advanced sample as it tries to mimic a sequence of screens of a real app. That samples separates each screen in its own Element with a parent element coordinating them. Note that the “child” elements doesn’t know anything about the parent element. The dependency is one way, thus helping maintain a healthy code.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_28.name: ef33
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_28.text:
AllanHasegawa/kelm
This sample showcases a real world sign up flow with multiple screens. Adding the entire update logic into a single…github.com

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_29.name: 83a5
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_29.text: Also, I have been successfully using the same ideas behind Kelm in production apps for more than 2 years now!

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_30.name: ef75
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_30.text: What about tests? It should be hard because of RxJava, right?

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_31.name: bfc1
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_31.text: 😉 Have you noticed how the Model, Messages and Commands are only data? They can be immutable data classes. The Update function is just a pure, synchronous function that takes data as input and outputs data.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_32.name: 75e4
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_32.text: In short, testing with Kelm is extreme easy and powerful. You don’t need to mock anything. You just pass data to the Update function and check it’s output. That’s it. It’s so easy to test with Kelm that writing tests before UI logic is usually the fastest way to code a new feature. Tests become just a very fast runtime. So when you finish a feature, you get it fully tested for free.

Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_35.name: 27ae
Paragraph:4e012b4c74ae_35.text: Wait until you see Kelm with Jetpack Compose ;)
